title: A whistle stop tour of {ggsurvfit}
text:
Motivation and why {ggsurvfit} ?
Overview of package functionality
Additional examples

title: A whistle stop tour of {ggsurvfit}
text:
A widely used statistical summary

Time-to-event (a.k.a Survival or Kaplan-Meier) summaries are commonplace, from oncology to cardiovascular.
KM displays the estimated cumulative proportion over time of patients who survive (or report an event)
However, it was not such a simple start:
John Tukey insisted Edward L. Kaplan and Paul Meier combine their efforts after submitting independent papers to JASA, which took 4 more years for the authors of the â€œKMâ€ estimator to publish
Afterwards â€œPaul Meier himself is said to have spoken with bemusement about people plotting KM estimates over time and was not convinced he actually liked itâ€ Morris et al, 2018


library(survival)
fit <- survfit(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) 
plot(fit)

title: A whistle stop tour of {ggsurvfit}
text:
Can we do better?

There are many design and analytical choices to be made when designing even a simple KM plot â€“ these choices can lead to wide variation in presentation quality.


library(ggsurvfit)
fit2 <- survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) 
ggsurvfit(fit2)

title: A whistle stop tour of {ggsurvfit}
text:
{ggsurvfit} overview

Ease the creation of time-to-event summary figures with ggplot2
Concise and modular code
Ready for publication or sharing figures
Sensible defaults
Supports CDISC data model
Also supports competing risks cumulative incidence summaries

title: Additional examples
text:
{ggsurvfit} defaults

gg_default <-
  survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |>
  ggsurvfit() +
  add_confidence_interval() +
  labs(title = "Default")

gg_default

title: Additional examples
text:
{ggplot2} styled

gg_styled <-
  gg_default +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 8)) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    limits = c(0, 1),
    labels = scales::percent, 
    expand = c(0.01, 0)
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 0:9, expand = c(0.02, 0)) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c('#54738E', '#82AC7C')) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c('#54738E', '#82AC7C')) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(ncol = 1)) +
  labs(
    title = "{ggplot2} styled",
    y = "Percentage Survival"
  )

gg_styled

title: Additional examples
text:
Side-by-side

library(patchwork)
gg_default + gg_styled

title: Additional examples
text:
{ggsurvfit} defaults

survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |>
  ggsurvfit() +
  add_risktable()

title: Additional examples
text:
Group by statistic or strata

ggrisktable <-
  survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |>
  ggsurvfit() +
  scale_ggsurvfit() +
  add_risktable(risktable_group = "risktable_stats") 
ggrisktable

title: Additional examples
text:
Colour encoding strata

ggrisktable +
  add_risktable_strata_symbol(symbol = "\U25CF", size = 10)

title: Additional examples
text:
Customizing the risktable statistics

survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |>
  ggsurvfit() +
  add_risktable(risktable_stats = "{n.risk} ({cum.event})")

title: Additional examples
text:
Median summary

survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |>
  ggsurvfit(linewidth = 0.8) +
  add_quantile(y_value = 0.5) +
  scale_ggsurvfit()

title: Additional examples
text:
At a given timepoint

survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |>
  ggsurvfit(linewidth = 0.8) +
  add_quantile(x_value = 5, linetype = "solid", 
               linewidth = 1.0, alpha = 0.3) +
  scale_ggsurvfit()

title: Data
text:
The following examples use a labeled version of the survival::colon data set.



library(ggsurvfit)

Loading required package: ggplot2

library(gtsummary)
library(tidyverse)

â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€
âœ” dplyr     1.1.2     âœ” readr     2.1.4
âœ” forcats   1.0.0     âœ” stringr   1.5.0
âœ” lubridate 1.9.2     âœ” tibble    3.2.1
âœ” purrr     1.0.1     âœ” tidyr     1.3.0


â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€

âœ– dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()

title: Basic Example
text:
Basic Example



survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |> 
  ggsurvfit() +
  add_risktable()








The Good

Simple code and figure is nearly publishable
Risk table with both no. at risk and events easily added
x-axis label taken from the time column label
Can use ggplot2 + notation

The Could-Be-Better

y-axis label is incorrect, and the range of axis is best at 0-100%
Axis padding a bit more than I prefer for a KM figure
x-axis typically has more tick marks for KM figure








Basic Example



survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |> 
  ggsurvfit() +
  add_risktable() +
  scale_ggsurvfit() +
  labs(y = "Recurrence-free Progression")








Padding has been reduced and curves begin in the upper left corner of plot
x-axis reports additional time points (and as a result, the risk table as well)
We updated the y-axis label weaving standard ggplot2 functions







Basic Example



survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |> 
  ggsurvfit() +
  add_risktable() +
  scale_ggsurvfit() +
  labs(y = "Recurrence-free Progression") +
  ggeasy::easy_move_legend("top")







Padding has been reduced and curves begin in the upper left corner of plot
x-axis reports additional time points (and as a result, the risk table as well)
We updated the y-axis label weaving standard ggplot2 functions
We can even use ggplot2-extender functions

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
Authors



Daniel D. Sjoberg
 



Mark Baillie

title: Outline
text:
Outline


Overview of package functionality
Discussion for ggplot2-extenders




Data
Examples use a labeled version of the survival::colon data set.



library(ggsurvfit)

Loading required package: ggplot2

library(gtsummary)
library(tidyverse)

â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€
âœ” dplyr     1.1.2     âœ” readr     2.1.4
âœ” forcats   1.0.0     âœ” stringr   1.5.0
âœ” lubridate 1.9.2     âœ” tibble    3.2.1
âœ” purrr     1.0.1     âœ” tidyr     1.3.0


â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€
âœ– dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
âœ– dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
â„¹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

df_colon <- df_colon |> select(time, status, surg)
df_colon

# A tibble: 929 Ã— 3
    time status surg                       
   <dbl>  <dbl> <fct>                      
 1 2.65       1 Limited Time Since Surgery 
 2 8.45       0 Limited Time Since Surgery 
 3 1.48       1 Limited Time Since Surgery 
 4 0.671      1 Extended Time Since Surgery
 5 1.43       1 Extended Time Since Surgery
 6 2.48       1 Limited Time Since Surgery 
 7 0.627      1 Extended Time Since Surgery
 8 8.74       0 Limited Time Since Surgery 
 9 8.69       0 Limited Time Since Surgery 
10 9.06       0 Extended Time Since Surgery
# â„¹ 919 more rows




df_colon |> 
  tbl_summary()





  
    
    
      Characteristic
      N = 9291
    
  
  
    Follow-up time, years
4.24 (1.01, 6.27)
    Recurrence Status
468 (50%)
    Time from Surgery to Treatment

    Â Â Â Â Limited Time Since Surgery
682 (73%)
    Â Â Â Â Extended Time Since Surgery
247 (27%)
  
  
  
    
      1 Median (IQR); n (%)
    
  








Basic Example



survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |> 
  ggsurvfit() +
  add_risktable()








The Good

Simple code and figure is nearly publishable
Risk table with both no. at risk and events easily added
x-axis label taken from the time column label
Can use ggplot2 + notation

The Could-Be-Better

y-axis label is incorrect, and the range of axis is best at 0-100%
Axis padding a bit more than I prefer for a Kaplan-Meier figure
x-axis typically has more tick marks for Kaplan-Meier figure








Basic Example



survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |> 
  ggsurvfit() +
  add_risktable() +
  scale_ggsurvfit() +
  labs(y = "Recurrence-free Progression")








Padding has been reduced and curves begin in the upper left corner of plot
x-axis reports additional time points (and as a result, the risk table as well)
We updated the y-axis label weaving standard ggplot2 functions







Basic Example



survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |> 
  ggsurvfit() +
  add_risktable() +
  scale_ggsurvfit() +
  labs(y = "Recurrence-free Progression") +
  ggeasy::easy_move_legend("top")







Padding has been reduced and curves begin in the upper left corner of plot
x-axis reports additional time points (and as a result, the risk table as well)
We updated the y-axis label weaving standard ggplot2 functions
We can even use ggplot2-extender functions






Another Example

survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |>
  ggsurvfit(type = "risk", linewidth = 1.2) +
  add_confidence_interval() +
  add_risktable(risktable_stats = "n.risk") +
  add_risktable_strata_symbol(symbol = "\U25CF", size = 17) +
  add_quantile(x_value = 5, linetype = "dotted", linewidth = 0.8) +
  add_censor_mark(size = 2, alpha = 0.2) +
  add_pvalue(caption = "Log-rank {p.value}") +
  scale_ggsurvfit() +
  scale_color_manual(values = c('#54738E', '#82AC7C')) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c('#54738E', '#82AC7C')) +
  labs(y = "Risk of Recurrence")

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
ğŸ—“ July 21, 2023 | Time TBD
ğŸ¨ Roche Campus, Grenzacherstrasse 124, 4070 Basel, Switzerland
ğŸ’¥ Conference Registration through July 14th or until event sells out


Abstract
The {ggsurvfit} package eases the creation of time-to-event or survival analysis summary figures with {ggplot2}, such as a Kaplan-Meier plot. The concise and modular code creates figures ready for publication. Each {ggsurvfit} function (e.g.Â add_confidence_interval(), add_risktable(), etc.) is written as a proper {ggplot2} â€˜geomâ€™, meaning the package functions can be woven with {ggplot2} functions. The implication is that you do not need to learn new functions to style the plot: rather, you may rely on the suite of {ggplot2} functions you already know.
Lastly, the package includes gems for those using the CDISC ADaM ADTTE data model. The â€œPARAMâ€ value is used to construct enhanced labels in the figure. The event indicator, â€œCNSRâ€, is coded in the opposite way the {survival} package expects. This difference creates an opportunity for errors to be silently introduced in an analysis. The {ggsurvfit} package exports a function called Surv_CNSR() to resolve this concern by creating a survival object that uses ADTTE coding conventions as the default. The function can be used in {ggsurvfit} as well as any other package with a survival endpoint.
Install {ggsurvfit} from CRAN with
install.packages('ggsurvfit')


Authors

Daniel D. Sjoberg (he/him) is a Software Engineer at Genentech. Previously, he was a Lead Data Science Manager at the Prosate Cancer Clinical Trials Consortium, and a Senior Biostatistician at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York City. He enjoys R package development, creating many packages available on CRAN, R-Universe, and GitHub. His research interests include adaptive methods in clinical trials, precision medicine, and predictive modeling. Daniel is the winner of the 2021 American Statistical Association (ASA) Innovation in Statistical Programming and Analytics award.
    
 


Mark Baillie is a member of the Advanced Methodology and Data Science group at Novartis. He focuses on methodology to support drug development, working on a variety of internal and external initiatives to improve the reporting of clinical trials. These include effective visual communication, initial data analysis, DMC reporting, analaysis results standards, and data challenges. Mark is a member of the Stratos initiative and the PSI visualisation special interest group.

title: Introduction
text: This work is licensed under Creative Commons Zero v1.0 Universal.

title: Introduction
text:
Daniel D. Sjoberg
 



Mark Baillie

title: Outline
text:
Outline


Overview of package functionality
Discussion for ggplot2-extenders

Side-by-side plots with {patchwork}
Structure of {ggsurvfit} functions





Side-by-Side



library(ggsurvfit)

Loading required package: ggplot2

library(patchwork)

p <-
  survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ 1, df_colon) |> 
  ggsurvfit() +
  add_confidence_interval() +
  add_risktable() +
  scale_ggsurvfit()



# build plot (which constructs the risktable)
built_p <- ggsurvfit_build(p)

# wrap built plot to place side-by-side
p2 <- 
  wrap_elements(built_p) | 
  wrap_elements(built_p)









The risk tables are not built until print or running ggsurvfit_build()
Then you have to wrap the



Side-by-Side
How can we make this easier for ggsurvfit users?

IDEA 1

In patchwork, the first line the arithmetic operator is a conditional to assess if the object needs processing
We could make this operation an exported generic function!
Issue submitted in Nov 2022, but no response yet. https://github.com/thomasp85/patchwork/issues/310




Side-by-Side


Current patchwork   Proposed patchwork

if (should_autowrap(e2)) e2 <- wrap_elements(full = e2) 

should_autowrap <- function(x) {
    is.grob(x) || inherits(x, 'formula') || is.raster(x) || inherits(x, 'nativeRaster')
  }

#' @export
#' @rdname arithmetic_prep
arithmetic_prep <- function(x, ...) {
  UseMethod("arithmetic_prep")
}

#' @export
#' @rdname arithmetic_prep
arithmetic_prep.default <- function(x, ...) {
  # wrap input plot as needed
  if (is.grob(x) || inherits(x, 'formula') || is.raster(x) || inherits(x, 'nativeRaster')) {
    x <- wrap_elements(full = x)
  }
  x
}



Any tips on getting this through??



Side-by-Side

IDEA 2: S4 ğŸ˜¬ğŸ˜¬ğŸ˜¬

I reached out on Stack Overflow, but couldnâ€™t get the S4 solution to work
Also, I donâ€™t know anything about S4 ğŸ¤·
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/74072102




Function Stucture

The packageâ€™s functions work! Nice!
I think I may have implemented it in a strange way.
Is there better way? ğŸ¤”ğŸ¤”



Function Stucture
add_censor_mark <- function(...) {
  add_censor_mark_empty_list <- list()
  structure(add_censor_mark_empty_list,
            dots = utils::modifyList(x = list(na.rm = TRUE, size = 2, shape = 3),
                                     val = rlang::dots_list(...)),
            class = "add_censor_mark")
}

ggplot_add.add_censor_mark <- function (object, plot, object_name) {
  update_add_censor_mark(plot, object)
}

update_add_censor_mark <- function(p, add_censor_mark_empty_list) {
  # getting user-passed arguments
  dots <- attr(add_censor_mark_empty_list, "dots")

  # add censor marks with `geom_point()`
  p +
    rlang::inject(
      ggplot2::geom_point(
        data = ~ tidyr::uncount(.x, weights = .data$n.censor),
        ggplot2::aes(!!!.construct_censor_mark_aes(p)),
        !!!dots
      )
    )
}

title: KMunicate and themes
text:
There are many options to consider and many guidances available:


Morris et al.Â 2018 provide useful guidance for publication figures
To get figures that align with KMunicate use the theme_ggsurvfit_KMunicate() theme along with these function options.


A note of caution on standards:


Design for your purpose, one size does not fit all
Designing means you need to think carefully about your audience and aims







survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |>
  ggsurvfit(linetype_aes = TRUE) +
  add_confidence_interval() +
  add_risktable(
    risktable_stats = c("n.risk", "cum.censor", "cum.event")
  ) +
  theme_ggsurvfit_KMunicate() +
  scale_ggsurvfit() +
  theme(legend.position = c(0.85, 0.85)) +
  labs(y = "Recurrence-free Progression")

title: KMunicate and themes
text:

To get figures that align with KMunicate use the theme_ggsurvfit_KMunicate() theme along with these function options.


A note of caution on standards:


Design for your purpose, one size does not fit all
Designing means you need to think carefully about your audience and aims

text:
survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |>
  ggsurvfit(linetype_aes = TRUE) +
  add_confidence_interval() +
  add_risktable(
    risktable_stats = c("n.risk", "cum.censor", "cum.event")
  ) +
  theme_ggsurvfit_KMunicate() +
  scale_ggsurvfit() +
  theme(legend.position = c(0.85, 0.85)) +
  labs(y = "Recurrence-free Progression")

title: {ggsurvfit} wrap up
text:
{ggsurvfit} wrap up

Ease the creation of time-to-event summary figures with ggplot2
Concise and modular code
Ready for publication or sharing figures
Sensible defaults
Also supports competing risks cumulative incidence summaries


# Install ggsurvfit from CRAN with:
install.packages("ggsurvfit")

# install.packages("devtools"):
devtools::install_github("pharmaverse/ggsurvfit")

title: Back-up examples
text:
Left over examples removed from main deck


In addition to using additional {ggplot2} functions, it is helpful to understand which underlying functions are used to create the figures.


survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ 1, data = df_colon) %>%
  ggsurvfit(color = "#508050") +
  add_confidence_interval(fill = "#508050")

title: Back-up examples
text:
In addition to using additional {ggplot2} functions, it is helpful to understand which underlying functions are used to create the figures.


survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ 1, data = df_colon) %>%
  ggsurvfit(color = "#508050") +
  add_confidence_interval(fill = "#508050")

title: Back-up examples
text:
Further customization

survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) %>%
  ggsurvfit(linewidth = 0.8) +
  add_risktable(
    risktable_height = 0.33,
    size = 4, # increase font size of risk table statistics
    theme =   # increase font size of risk table title and y-axis label
      list(
        theme_risktable_default(axis.text.y.size = 11, 
                                plot.title.size = 11),
        theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"))
      )
  )

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
Licensing

This work is licensed under Creative Commons Zero v1.0 Universal.

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
Authors



Daniel D. Sjoberg
 



Mark Baillie

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
A widely used statistical summary

Time-to-event (a.k.a Survival or Kaplan-Meier) summaries are commonplace, from oncology to cardiovascular.
KM displays the estimated cumulative proportion over time of patients who survive (or report an event)
However, it was not such a simple start:
John Tukey insisted Edward L. Kaplan and Paul Meier combine their efforts after submitting independent papers to JASA, which took 4 more years for the authors of the â€œKMâ€ estimator to publish
Afterwards â€œPaul Meier himself is said to have spoken with bemusement about people plotting KM estimates over time and was not convinced he actually liked itâ€ Morris et al, 2018


library(survival)
fit <- survfit(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) 
plot(fit)

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
Can we do better?

There are many design and analytical choices to be made when designing even a simple KM plot â€“ these choices can lead to wide variation in presentation quality.


library(ggsurvfit)
fit2 <- survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) 
ggsurvfit(fit2)

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
{ggsurvfit} overview

Ease the creation of time-to-event summary figures with ggplot2
Concise and modular code
Ready for publication or sharing figures
Sensible defaults
Supports CDISC data model
Also supports competing risks cumulative incidence summaries

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
Use ggplot2 functions

Each ggsurvfit add-on function is written as a proper ggplot2 geom
Enables package functions woven with ggplot2 functions seamlessly
Donâ€™t need to learn to style with ggsurvfit functions
Use your ggplot2 knowledge if you want to customize

Limitless customization

Modify x-axis scales or any other plot feature and risk table will still align with plot

Simple saving and export through ggplot2::ggsave()

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
Ready to publish legends

Raw variable names do not appear in the figure


fit <- survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) 
survminer::ggsurvplot(fit)
ggsurvfit(fit)

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
{ggsurvfit} defaults

gg_default <-
  survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |>
  ggsurvfit() +
  add_confidence_interval() +
  labs(title = "Default")

gg_default

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
{ggplot2} styled

gg_styled <-
  gg_default +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 8)) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    limits = c(0, 1),
    labels = scales::percent, 
    expand = c(0.01, 0)
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 0:9, expand = c(0.02, 0)) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c('#54738E', '#82AC7C')) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c('#54738E', '#82AC7C')) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom") +
  guides(color = guide_legend(ncol = 1)) +
  labs(
    title = "{ggplot2} styled",
    y = "Percentage Survival"
  )

gg_styled

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text: {ggplot2} styled

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
Side-by-side

library(patchwork)
gg_default + gg_styled

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
{ggsurvfit} defaults

survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |>
  ggsurvfit() +
  add_risktable()

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
Group by statistic or strata

ggrisktable <-
  survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |>
  ggsurvfit() +
  scale_ggsurvfit() +
  add_risktable(risktable_group = "risktable_stats") 
ggrisktable

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
Colour encoding strata

ggrisktable +
  add_risktable_strata_symbol(symbol = "\U25CF", size = 10)

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
Customizing the risktable statistics

survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |>
  ggsurvfit() +
  add_risktable(risktable_stats = "{n.risk} ({cum.event})")

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
Median summary

survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |>
  ggsurvfit(linewidth = 0.8) +
  add_quantile(y_value = 0.5) +
  scale_ggsurvfit()

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
At a given timepoint

survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |>
  ggsurvfit(linewidth = 0.8) +
  add_quantile(x_value = 5, linetype = "solid", 
               linewidth = 1.0, alpha = 0.3) +
  scale_ggsurvfit()

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
section: What are the elements of an effective and publishable KM plot?
text:
What are the elements of an effective and publishable KM plot?
There are many options to consider and many guidances available:


Morris et al.Â 2018 provide useful guidance for publication figures
To get figures that align with KMunicate use the theme_ggsurvfit_KMunicate() theme along with these function options.


A note of caution on standards:


Design for your purpose, one size does not fit all
Designing means you need to think carefully about your audience and aims

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text:
KMunicate

survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) |>
  ggsurvfit(linetype_aes = TRUE) +
  add_confidence_interval() +
  add_risktable(
    risktable_stats = c("n.risk", "cum.censor", "cum.event")
  ) +
  theme_ggsurvfit_KMunicate() +
  scale_ggsurvfit() +
  theme(legend.position = c(0.85, 0.85)) +
  labs(y = "Recurrence-free Progression")

title: Visualizing Survival Data with the {ggsurvfit} R Package
text: KMunicate

title: Why {ggsurvfit} ?
text:
Each ggsurvfit add-on function is written as a proper ggplot2 geom
Enables package functions woven with ggplot2 functions seamlessly
Donâ€™t need to learn to style with ggsurvfit functions
Use your ggplot2 knowledge if you want to customize

Limitless customization

Modify x-axis scales or any other plot feature and risk table will still align with plot

Simple saving and export through ggplot2::ggsave()




Raw variable names do not appear in the figure


fit <- survfit2(Surv(time, status) ~ surg, data = df_colon) 
survminer::ggsurvplot(fit)
ggsurvfit(fit)
